data.title: silly
data.meta_description: SILLY definition: 1. showing little thought or judgment:  2. embarrassed; afraid that people will laugh at you:  3…. Learn more.
data.text:
adjective

uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈsɪl.i/ us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈsɪl.i/

B1

Don't do that, you silly boy!

a silly mistake

silly of It was silly of you to go out in the sun without a hat.

Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples

stupidSome people are too stupid to realize what's bad for them.

foolishShe was really foolish to quit her job like that.

sillyIt was silly of you to go out in the sun without a hat.

crazyYou'd be absolutely crazy to marry that man.

dumbUS She was terrified of asking dumb questions.

See more results »

B1

She gets upset over such silly things.

We were served our drinks in these silly little glasses.

More examplesFewer examples

What's the name of that guy on TV - you know, the American one with the silly voice?

They can't expect me to accommodate all their silly little likes and dislikes.

Why are you putting on that silly voice?

I screamed myself silly on the roller coaster.

Seriously now, did he really say that or are you just being silly?

SMART Vocabulary: related words and phrases

You can also find related words, phrases, and synonyms in the topics:

sports specialized

in cricket, relating to the position of a fielder (= a player who tries to stop the other team from scoring by stopping or catching the ball) which is very close to the batter (= the player who tries to hit the ball):

silly mid-off He caught the ball almost at silly mid-off.

silly mid-on Wilkes has his foot on the pitch as he fields at silly mid-on.

silly point The captain decided to bring another fielder in close to the wicket and moved himself to silly point.

(Definition of silly from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

silly | American Dictionary

silly

adjective

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈsɪl·i/

silliness

noun [ U ] us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/ˈsɪl·i·nəs/

It’s time to stop the silliness and get serious.

(Definition of silly from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of silly

silly

It was perfectly all right to say silly things.

No, how silly, it came from ancient boreal forests, further afield, and was blown off course.

But this is a silly question (at least for anyone who takes justice seriously enough to raise it).

Unfortunately - if not surprisingly - each of these senses, in isolation, comes off sounding rather silly.

It is silly to focus on achieving spontaneity or pleasure in what one does, so the observation goes.

To ask whether it is real or authentic is a silly question.

When the time came for the experimenter to elicit these words, she told the child that they would now be playing a silly word game.

I found this argument to be rather silly.

However, only the silly word game productions were compared with child productions.

These questions are all silly for integers because we treat integers as values, not objects.

I am not suggesting that it is in principle silly to think that behaviors of this sort could be underwritten by genes.

The experimenter told the child that she would say some silly words, and the child should repeat these silly words back to her.

The idea of total transparency is silly, if not incoherent.

Children were told to read some silly, meaningless words.

What they probably mean is that they are afraid to sing in case someone thinks they sound silly.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
